segments.text: Okay, so you didn't— They didn't get to— Well, we were delayed at Camp Sutton for several months after we pulled out of Camp Shelby.
We were delayed at Camp Sutton for several months, and then we got from there, we were the first regiment to go into the famous embarkation camp near Rutgers.
That's the name for the guy that wrote the poem.
I think that I shall never see
I shall never write a poem as noble as a tree or whatever it is.
You know that poem?
Is that Forever England, that one?
No, that's this American poet that wrote Trees.
I think that I shall never see a poem prettier than a tree, a tree that blah blah blah blah blah.
We went up to camp.
It's just outside of Rutgers, New Jersey, on the north side.
And that was the staging area where you waited for the ships to come.
Now the whole movement was delayed by the shortage of shipping.
And another thing that delayed it
is that the great white father, Roosevelt, had promised his friend Winston Churchill that America would have an expeditionary force coming to the British Isles without delay.
So you went to Britain then?
And yeah without delay and we will we'll
Whip Hitler first, then we'll gang up and get rid of the other war.
Well, what the great white father forgot was that the Japs weren't weak.
When they spread out down there and wiped out the Asiatic fleet, which was a very weak sister, the old admiral that commanded it was
had the biggest job to cry over after his fleet was wiped out than anybody in the service.
But when he was wiped out and the Japs had opened their war against anybody that had a colony that they wanted, all the way from Burma
to the best holdings of the Dutch and the East Indies included.
They took the whole thing and moved in with massive forces and followed up on the victory at Pearl Harbor.
They followed it up and exploited it to the nth degree.
and that gave the president a second thought with his admirals and his generals breathing pretty hard down his neck, including his choice general.
I mentioned him a moment ago.
Marshal.
Marshal.
So you probably, you didn't get to England until 1943.
No, I got to England shortly after Labor Day.
Of 42.
Of 42.
And you trained there then for the next 18 months waiting to go, waiting to invade in D-Day.
We went at first to our first village.
We were in North Ireland.
and we moved in the village that had been occupied by the British.
Well the British had an army that was disarmed when they left their guns and material on the beaches of Holland following the retreat from the... after the collapse of France.
They had no place to go and they left that there.

Well, that army that was pushed out of there was re-militated in North Ireland, resumed training until the industry of England could re-equip them with arms and ammunition to take the place of what they had left on the beaches at the evacuation from the continent.
and disastrous evacuation.
Well these people were getting pretty well trained and pretty well armed.
So you worked with them?
So as they flowed out, this big force magnet moved into the billets that the English
had pulled out of, and bear in mind that the English was under a threat of invasion in Europe all summer.
So as fast as they could get people with guns and equipment down there ready to resist that impending invasion, which was as bogus as a ten dollar counterfeit.
But they didn't know it.
They didn't know it.
So you trained for the next 18 months, more than that, in North Ireland and in England, and you went to, you were in on the Normandy invasion.
That's right.
Now tell me about the Normandy invasion.
When did you go ashore?
Well let me give you a connecting link there.
We stayed in North Ireland until New Year's Eve.
And then we moved, our cannon and whatnot were moved on by railroad to a town in England named
You went to this town Devizes?
That's in Wiltshire.
And you were ready to stage the operation across the channel?
No.
Or you were preparing for it?
It was at this time that you became the commander in 1942 of the 190th Field Artillery Regiment.
That's right.
Which you commanded throughout the rest of the war.
That's right.
Now did you, were you promoted to a Brigadier General?
No.
You didn't get promoted overseas?
Okay.
All your promotions, if you wanted to be promoted, you should get a staff job in Washington, D.C. Tell me about the invasion.
Tell me about D-Day.
Well, no, it's too much between.
We were in North Ireland until New Year's Eve.
and then we displaced down to Wiltshire at Devizes and that put us next door to the British Army training field and artillery range at near Salisbury that is mentioned so often in Kipling's coins.
and so on about the British Army.
So, it's all very plain and we did considerable training in firing and in that area and it was a wonderful experience because the first thing that happened to a force magnet was that when they got
one infantry division and one armored division out of force magnet.
Roosevelt kind of doubled across Winston Churchill and didn't tell him that he had reduced the size of magnet

from four or five divisions because the Jap victories and seizures from Burma across the Pacific had forced him to detach the 32nd Division, which I repeat again was the first division alerted by General
by General Kruger.
The first division, Kruger's order was to turn out the four or five most ready divisions he had and to get them over his magnet.
Then when the tide turned against the magnet, Roosevelt without
telling me he was going to do it, just arbitrarily took about half of the magnet force and diverted it to the South Pacific.
The first thing I knew that there was trouble in the magnet force was while I was in Alabama awaiting the move to the port of embarkation.
While I was there training the 190th Regiment as a part of the 73rd F.A.
Brigade.
While I was there I got a postcard from a professor that was a major in the 32nd Division and he was going overseas

by train to San Francisco and I didn't know those divisions and then cut off the magnet force until a postcard came from him mailed in Salt Lake City and he was on a troop train headed for San Francisco
and the South Pacific to join MacArthur.
So, the 32nd Division stripped of its down to a triangular division was headed for the South Pacific.
And of course, he didn't tell me
where they were going in the South City, except there was a fellow named Sidney that had visited our college and made some kind of long-winded speech.
And he was a graduate of our college and knew a lot of people.
So this ex-prof of mine says,
says, the Utah address will surprise you.
Says, I have no idea where we're going, but I will happily see the guy that listed us such and such a date.
And well, here's that guy and date and circumstances.
was obviously Sydney.
So he says, I expect to see him there.
It was a disguised breach of regulations.
In other words, he was telling me that they were headed for Sydney, Australia.
So in other words, your force was much smaller than
than Churchill had hoped, meaning that you had to stay longer in England for it to build up.
Churchill was a disappointed man when he got that news and we continued over there training and so one day a British general, now I teamed up with the British, I got along happily with them.
I had read most of their novels
I was pretty sharp on the governmental methods.
I bought two books at Rutgers.
One of them was Geographical History.
It was an economic geography of the British Isles.
It was by a fellow named
He was a professor at London University named...
So you got, you had read a lot in New York.
Well I bought those two books.
I bought that book and another book on England on British government.
The Duties of the House, The Limitations, and it was a recent edition.
It was strictly a political science textbook, but it was recent enough to be quite helpful.
So riding on the ship over there, you've got to do something, you've got to read something.
What did you think of the quality of the British officer?
The quality of the British officers?
They're just like all officers.
Some are good, some are disasters.
So you must have trained with them while your force was increasing in size.
Yeah, we went on tours with them.
I mean maneuvers and we took our guns down there.
I never fired on our guns anywhere on the British range.

that half a dozen of the faculty of the gunnery school on Salisbury Plain would be there, and the British, their mouths were watering for those, what they called, long toms, and they were dying to get issued.
In fact, they were
begging, they said they ought to have at least eight of these guns for each corps.
They thought that the British corps was somewhat smaller than the American corps.
But to cover the entire front of the entire corps zone of responsibility, they needed eight of those guns.
and every time I fired them there'd be a bunch of their officers down, two or three or four.
Now did you have, were you built up to size by D-Day?
By D-Day, yes.
While I was, that's another story.
When we moved out of the, out of the
embarkation area, when we embarked on the Queen Elizabeth to go across North Ireland, we had every man in a slot for every skill and every, he might not have the full skill yet.
He hadn't been with us.
But you were a full complement.
Absolutely.
The big worry in that transportation corps, you were in the hands of the transportation corps at that stage of the game.
You weren't in anybody else's hands and you wrote your own ticket on what training you could do.
And of course I organized schools for
everybody in the regiment and I kept them busy.
And it's hard to keep a couple of thousand men busy when their hardware is already on the seas headed to Europe ahead of them and they're there marking time for enough ships to come in.
It's hard to keep them busy.
Now let's talk about D-Day.
Well, that's a long story by itself.
Did you go in on the second day, D plus one?
I was, that's another story.
How much time you got?
Well, I want to find out about your campaigns.
You were in a number of campaigns.
And of course D-Day is very important.
You were in five campaigns from D-Day to Germany.
Well, the buildup for D-Day was actually more strenuous.
than perhaps D-Day itself in some respects.

There's a little bit more nervous strain on D-Day immediately thereafter, but as far as the hard work and everything, there was an awful lot of hard work done before D-Day and a lot of shuffling around.
People say, well what were you doing over there?
What were you doing in the war effort?
The 1st Armored Division was transferred out of North Ireland to Africa.
The 34th Division was transferred out of North Ireland to Africa.
How in the hell did you get stranded up there and what are you doing now to make the world safe for democracy?
Well, you've got to answer questions like that.
When there's an active campaign in Africa, what are you doing at all?
A British colonel gave me the tip
as your command gets more publicity in our papers than our training does.
I says, yes, I notice it.
They come down and take our pictures once in a while.
And I says, what do you think that adds up to?
He says, I don't know, but I thought you might know.
I says, well, I'll meditate on it a little bit.
So, next time I see him, maybe I'll have an answer.
Well, I got the answer, but I never told him.
What the British were doing, they were using us for show troops to make the Germans think that the fifth,
force magnet was still 100% in the British Isles.
And what they were doing is every once in a while when we would be training on a new different, we fired on every range they had in the British Isles south of Scotland.
I don't know if they got any ranges in Scotland, I don't know where they were.
We fired on the range there in Salisbury plain.
We fired repeatedly from the range on down close to Oakhampton.
That's the, where, that's the, you've read the, That Hound of Baskervilles by
A great detective writer.
We fired on that range.
So you were prepared by D-Day?
Hell, we were over trained by D-Day.
We were, we fired on the Bodman movers that are famous in all the novels of this gal that writes
stories about that part of England.
We were lucky in that we got plenty of ammunition to fire, and what the British were doing
They would take picture of my guns, always with the men looking in the direction of the muzzle, and with their backs to the camera, and it would appear in some or three or four British newspapers.
Recently arrived Yanks, trained with British Tommies on an undisclosed artillery,
So it was propaganda.
Propaganda 100%.
In other words, the Germans knew that every corps had one of these regiments.
So here we were being stooges.
Sure.
And the Germans in their map of, in their distribution of the enemy would immediately chalk up well
Hell, there's another one and there's another corps.
So what we were doing, we were a part of the facade of what wasn't happening.
The British were quite good at propaganda.
Now what beach did you land at?
On Omaha Bay Beach.

We fired, I found a stock of 75 millimeter ammunition down there that the British had built up to train their people to use the French 75s and they took the French 75s away from our people being trained
that first year we were on active duty.
They stripped some of those guns away from us, brought them over there.
One of my officers discovered where they were stored.
They were stored hub to hub and hundreds of them that they had pulled together and he came back and says, if we still had
The old gun says we could be equipped with new tubes and everything.
I said, well I think we can get equipped with new tubes anyway before we go across the channel because they aren't going to send a regiment in combat with 50% worn out tubes and so I said,
By the way, where's the ammunition that goes with those guns?
They haven't shot it up.
He says, I can find out.
So I says, find out.
He found something like 50,000 rounds in some damn little ordnance storeroom over there close to their artillery range.
and I said make a date with me for me with the supply officer down there at Salisbury and we got to talk about that stuff.
I said we aren't getting enough firing through our own tubes.
I have to keep 2,000 rounds of ammunition
with me.
And I says they won't let me touch more than just a small percent of that to fire through the tubes.
And their plea is that it wears the tubes out too soon.
And I says we've got to get a cure for that because we're not really shooting enough stuff to see whether our surveys and our preparatory patterns
of fire are to be done, and we can do that with the French 75's if they had them.
We could aim and go through the loading exercise of the big gun, then the little gun is sitting here on a parallel setting
and it's got a range of 8,000 to 11,000 yards depending upon whether you have the new boat tail projectile or the new powder.
It says we can get 11,000 yards on that.
I says we can go out there and fire on targets within 11,000 yards with these short guns
instead of wearing out the tubes on our long guns and we'll just fire once in a while out of the long gun and stay within the limited ammunition that way.
Well on that ticket, I went down to the artillery school on Salisbury Plain and talked to the
higher chief there and asked him what he was going to do with all these French 75 rounds.
He says, melt them down for automobiles after the war, I presume.
I said, well I can melt down quite a few of them if you'll just lift the lid on them.
He says, oh well, what do you want with them?
I says, I know where I can get
12, I never fire more than a battalion concentration and that would mean 12 tubes.
I'll never fire more than that and I says I can set this and I told him what I wanted.
In other words I wanted to do some what you'd call excalibur exercises and
If you can do a good Excalibur exercise, you can do a darn sight easier and quicker.
I'd ram it in and shoot itself, but I could get on any time I could get on a range.
I could go out on my own order, didn't have to ask anybody.
Say I'm, except I would report to my headquarters,
that we were going to fire for so many days on Bodden and Range, and we'd go out there with all that free ammunition.
We'd load the things up and then we'd poop them out with great prodigality.
We would fire a widespread sheaf, a closed sheaf, and you couldn't lie about whether it was good or bad because
there was the pattern out in front of you.
You could see it through the BC scope looking at the impacts area, and so we built up quite a reputation among the British as being an ingenious training group.
They invited me down to the artillery school one time to talk to their
officers about their faculty about what they were doing.
And they didn't know it, but we had a $500 survey instrument for each battalion.
One of the finest transits that these ordinary surveyors around here buy.
And
The British didn't call it a transit.
They called it a theodolite.
So, they asked me and my executive officer to come down.
One of the fellows wanted to make a report on the way we were doing this thing to his colleagues at the artillery school.
And he says, now these Americans do it this way.
And while the guns are moving into position, the survey squad does this.
The battalion survey squad does that.
The battalion detail that goes up to the observation post does that.
So, we were supposed to answer all the questions.
Now, this fella had walked through a big chute with us, and he wanted us to be there to explain anything he couldn't explain.
And when he got through, he says, are there any questions?
And one of the first questions he got is says, says, who takes charge?
of him placing the guns while all these officers are out there doing this survey work here, there, and yonder.
Who takes their place?
Who does that?
And the fellow making the speech said, well, I really don't know.
He says, I hadn't thought of that, but now that you raise it up,
There is something about the Yanks are able to do things that we can't do.
He says, we think that it takes an officer to do all this survey work.
He says, this work in the American Army is done by sergeants.
And you say, well sergeant, yeah sure.
He says, I want to tell you something.
The knowledge and skills of the American enlisted men are far superior to that of our people.
He says, our leaving home age is 14.
Grammar school, not high school.
says our leaving school age is 14, their leaving school age is 18.
And where that happens, you can get sergeants that can run a survey.
And so he says, turned to me and he says, now you vouch for the fact that all these details were
done by a sergeant?"
I said, yes, absolutely.
And I says, don't worry about any deficiency.
I read in the papers that you're going to revise your entire educational system and put it up to the 16 and 18 level.
And I says, when you do, you'll get sergeants.
How'd you get along with the French people?
No kidding?
Why do you say that?
Once you got into France, how were your relations?
You just had poor relations with them in France?
Well, my second day on D-Day, after D-Day, my second day after, well,
I got ashore about 10 a.m. with the tide coming in on D plus one.
Now at that time the, our troops were on the beach holding on like a hair by the skin of their teeth and the entire
Our ship and the ships around it, patrol boats and whatnot, were all under artillery fire, but it was the most incompetent artillery fire I ever saw the Germans do.
They were obviously firing on area targets.
without adjustment for wind direction, without adjustments for powder temperature, without adjustment for any of the refining things that you do before you really poop out a long range missile.
That's what a cannonball is, or a projector.
How much Army experience have you had, pretty much?
Three years.
Three years.
Which?
I was in a Navy gunfire.
Well, you know what I'm talking about when I say that you don't just ram the damn projection through the breach, then throw in the charge, back off and poop it out.
You adjust.
or at your fire control center, you adjust for winds, powder temperature, just every damn little thing that can affect the flight of that projectile to its target.
So, the British did very little of that artillery, ground artillery.
They believed we'll see the burst
But why do you dislike the French?
Well, about D plus three we were already ashore and shooting.
And I had occasion to go back to the beach to see about
the arrival of ammunition, resupply of ammunition for our particular guns.
And when I got through that gulch that the Corps headquarters were in, I saw a friend of mine named Ford, who was the intelligence officer for the 5th Corps.
His name was Ford.
I knew Ford quite well, and I said, Ford, I just want to ask you one question.
He said, what is it?
Then I'll ask you a few.
I said, how many Frenchmen out of these underground Frenchmen
French freedom fighters.
How many of them have come in here and reported himself as being on our side?
And I says the woods must be full of them around here because this is a surprise attack and some of these installations may have been under their attack.
Has anybody shown up out of the underground
or anywhere else and said, give me a gun, I want to get in on the killing of a few Germans.
And he said, well that's a rather brutal question to ask.
He says, but I can't answer it.
He says, yes, one of them has come in and reported himself for duty.
I says, where is he?
He said, he's right over there.
He says, we've got him busy, don't worry.
And he says, he's valuable to us, so don't talk too damn loud.
He says, there he is.
I said, well, which one of these undergrounds was he?
And he says, I don't know.
I haven't talked to him enough.
But he says, I do know one thing.
He was the spy that we had on the job.
that was reporting the condition of the beaches and all that stuff, so he says, he's a valuable man, don't bother him.
And that was the first, I had a feeling that out of those basements,
Of course all the civilians, French civilians, went into the deepest basement they could find, or they knew what to do when they knew they were on the battlefield.
They knew to take to the nearest forest and huddle up around any cottage or anything like that that would offer any shelter
Shell fire, anything like that?
So you thought basically the French were chickens.
You're damn right.
Now, after D.D., there was the breakthrough, and the American armed forces were moving very, very rapidly all the way into Belgium.
And the next major event was the Battle of the Bulge, in which, what was your role in the Battle of the Bulge?
We were right on the nose of it.
We, our guns were deployed at
